novel_text:
The dust was a living thing. It had its own moods, its own seasons. In the spring, it was a fine, pale powder that clung to the air like a ghost’s memory. By the scorched heart of summer, it was a coarse, angry grit that scoured the paint from the barn and worked its way into the marrow of your bones. Elara Vance knew the dust better than she knew most people. She’d been born in it, raised a life from it, and figured she’d be buried in it, too. Just another layer in the land’s long story.

She leaned against the fence post, the rough-hewn pine a familiar comfort against her back. Her belly, round and taut under the worn denim of her shirt, pressed against the top rail. A life, new and insistent, shifted within her. She grunted, a soft, animal sound, and placed a calloused hand over the swell. “Easy there, little one,” she murmured, her voice raspy from the dry air. “Nowhere to go just yet.” The sun was a merciless hammer in the sky, beating down on the cracked earth of the high plains. The heat shimmered over the distant mesas, making them dance and sway as if the world itself was unsteady on its feet.

Her gaze tracked the fence line, a long, snaking spine of wire and wood that marked the edge of her world. It was a good fence, strong. Her husband, Jed, had helped her sink the last posts, his laughter echoing in the vast emptiness as he’d swung the mallet. That was before. Before the night the laughter stopped, replaced by a silence so profound it felt like a physical weight. Now, she maintained the fence alone. A good fence was the first and last line of defense against the things that came with the dark. Coyotes, cattle rustlers, and worse.

Something was wrong. She’d felt it the moment she’d ridden out, a discordant note in the morning’s symphony of cicadas and wind. Her horse, a sturdy buckskin named Gideon, had been skittish, his ears twitching, his nostrils flaring. Now she saw it. Halfway down the line, a section of wire was snapped, the ends curled back like burnt matchsticks. And just beyond it, in the sparse shade of a lonely juniper tree, lay the carcass of a young steer.

Elara swore, a low, guttural curse that was swallowed by the immense landscape. She swung herself onto Gideon’s back, the movement less graceful than it used to be, her body feeling foreign and cumbersome. The horse needed no prompting, picking his way carefully over the rocky ground toward the dead animal. The smell hit her first—the coppery tang of blood, too faint on the hot wind but there all the same. It wasn't the work of a coyote pack. There was no tearing, no sign of a struggle. The steer lay on its side, its eyes wide and glassy, a small, neat puncture wound on its neck, almost surgical. It had been drained. Utterly. Its hide hung loose on its frame, a deflated leather bag.

They hadn't even bothered to feed properly. They’d taken a drink, a snack, and left the rest to rot in the sun. It was the wastefulness that angered her most. The sheer, arrogant carelessness of it. A coyote killed to eat, to survive. It was part of the circle. This… this was a violation. An insult. This was the work of the night-crawlers, the leeches, the things the old-timers called vampires and the rest of the world just called a goddamn nuisance. They were reckless, like teenagers with a new car and a death wish, only their joyride had been going on for a century and the world was their demolition derby. They broke things just to watch them fall.

She nudged Gideon with her heel, turning him away from the sight. No use dwelling on it. She’d have to drag the carcass out to the bluffs for the buzzards before it bloated. Another chore in a life that had become a long, repeating list of chores. As she rode, the baby kicked again, a sharp, insistent thump against her ribs. She winced, a flicker of a smile touching her lips despite herself. Jed had wanted a boy. A son to teach the ways of the ranch, to carry on the Vance name. He’d laid his head against her still-flat stomach and sworn he could hear the boy’s heart beating, strong and steady like a drum. “He’ll have your eyes,” he’d whispered, “and my stubborn streak.”

The memory was so clear it hurt, a shard of glass in her heart. He’d gone into town for supplies, a routine trip he’d made a hundred times. He’d been late. Then later still. Sheriff Brody found his truck a week later, parked by the side of the old highway, the driver’s side door swinging in the wind. No blood, no sign of a struggle. Just an empty truck and a man erased from the world. They’d taken him. Maybe for food, maybe for sport. With them, there was rarely a discernible reason. They just did.

The homestead appeared in the distance, a small, defiant collection of buildings against the endless expanse of brown and blue. The house, the barn, the windmill turning its slow, weary circle. A fortress. Every night, she bolted the heavy oak door and slid steel bars over the shutters. She kept a shotgun loaded with silver-laced buckshot by the bed and a revolver on the nightstand. She was safe. As safe as anyone could be. But the world was getting smaller. The leeches were getting bolder, their raids more frequent. They used to stick to the highways, preying on travelers. Then they started hitting the outlying towns. Now, they were punching through fence lines for a goddamn snack.

The sun was bleeding across the western horizon, painting the clouds in lurid shades of orange and purple as she reached the barn. She unsaddled Gideon, his warm, sweaty smell a comfort. He nudged her shoulder with his head, a silent question. “I know, boy,” she said, stroking his muzzle. “They’re pushing it.” She worked with an ingrained efficiency, topping up his water, throwing down fresh hay. The familiar rhythms of the work soothed the frayed edges of her nerves. These were things she could control. The setting of the sun was not.

Inside the small, tidy house, the air was still and warm. She lit a kerosene lamp, the soft, yellow light pushing back the encroaching shadows. The flame cast long, dancing shapes on the walls, making the familiar space seem strange and mutable. She stood for a moment in the center of the room, listening. The wind moaned around the corners of the house. The windmill creaked its steady, rhythmic complaint. And beneath it all, the profound, unnerving silence of the empty land. The silence where anything could be hiding. She went to the door, her hand resting on the smooth, cool wood. For a moment, she imagined not locking it. Just leaving it open, a gaping invitation into the dark. An end to the waiting, the constant, grinding tension. Let them come. Let it be over.

But then the baby moved, a gentle roll this time, a quiet assertion of its own existence. Her hand fell from the door to her belly. No. It wasn’t just her life anymore. She slid the heavy bolt home, the sound echoing in the quiet house like a judgment. She barred the windows, her movements methodical, a ritual against the night. She was a fortress, and the treasure she guarded was a life that hadn't even begun. A life she would protect with every last breath. She had no other choice.

The next days fell into a pattern of waiting. Elara found two more steers drained and discarded, their bodies bloating in the oppressive heat. The leeches were playing with her, leaving their kills like taunts on her doorstep. They were making a point, establishing a territory, or maybe they were just bored. She spent her days in a state of heightened awareness, every shadow a potential threat, every gust of wind a whisper of approaching danger. She worked with the shotgun slung over her shoulder, its weight a constant, grim reminder. The nights were worse. She slept in short, fitful bursts, waking at the slightest sound, her heart hammering against her ribs. The house, once a sanctuary, now felt like a cage.

She knew she couldn’t last like this. The ranch was too isolated, and she was just one woman. She needed supplies, but more than that, she needed information. She needed to look another human being in the eye and be reminded that she wasn't the last person on Earth. The town of Redemption was a two-hour ride away, a dusty outpost of frightened humanity huddled behind a ten-foot concrete wall. Leaving the ranch felt like a betrayal, leaving it vulnerable, but staying was a slow suicide.

She rode out at dawn, when the light was pale and the air was cool and the things of the night were sleeping off their bloody indulgences in whatever dark holes they called home. Redemption's gates were closed, as always. A grizzled man with a rifle peered down from a watchtower built into the wall. “It’s Vance!” she yelled up, her voice feeling small against the massive gate. “Open up!”

There was a grinding of gears and the heavy steel gate scraped open just wide enough for her and Gideon to slip through. It closed behind her with a deafening clang. The town was just as she remembered it: a single main street lined with dusty, sun-bleached storefronts. The people on the street moved with a furtive quickness, their gazes darting into the shadows, their shoulders hunched. Fear was the local currency.

Her first stop was the sheriff's office. The sign above the door read "Sheriff T. Brody," the paint peeling like a sunburn. Inside, the air was thick with the smell of stale coffee and desperation. Brody sat behind a cluttered desk, a large man whose frame seemed to have been worn down and compacted by years of thankless work. His face was a roadmap of exhaustion.

“Elara,” he said, not getting up. It wasn't a greeting so much as an acknowledgment of a recurring problem. “Don’t tell me. More cattle.”

“Three more,” she said, standing before his desk. “They’re getting sloppy. Leaving them right out in the open.”

Brody sighed, a sound that seemed to come from the soles of his boots. He ran a hand over his face. “They’re getting sloppy everywhere. Hit the Miller place two nights ago. Took two of his goats. Tore the door right off his barn. We found one of them, you know.” He gestured to a corner of the office. A young man, barely out of his teens, lay on the floor under a dusty blanket. His skin was unnaturally pale, his face gaunt. “He was hiding out in an old storm cellar. Got careless. The sun came up, and he got caught in a sliver of light from a crack in the door. Fried him like an egg.”

Elara looked at the dead thing on the floor. It looked pathetic, not monstrous. Just a boy in a dirty jacket. It was hard to reconcile this pitiable corpse with the terror of the night, with the arrogant waste she’d seen on her land.

“What’s the point, Brody?” she asked, the question breaking from her, raw and real. “What are we even doing? We patch the walls, we count the dead, we wait for the sun to come up. It’s not a life.”

“It’s the one we got,” he said, his voice flat. He looked at her stomach, his gaze softening for just a second. “You shouldn’t be out there alone, Elara. Not now. It’s not safe.”

“Nowhere is safe,” she retorted. “Is it safer in here? Breathing this stale air, waiting for the walls to fall?” She turned to leave, the anger a hot knot in her chest.

“Elara, wait.” Brody’s voice stopped her. “There’s talk. Rumors. The old women are whispering. They say the leeches are getting restless for a reason. They say they’re gathering. Being drawn by something.” He looked at her, his eyes full of a weary pity. “Just… be careful.”

She didn’t answer. She walked out into the oppressive sunlight, Brody’s words clinging to her like a shroud. Drawn by something. The phrase echoed in her mind. On the street, an old woman selling dried herbs from a cart watched her pass, her eyes lingering on Elara’s swollen belly. The woman made a small, warding gesture with her fingers, a quick, furtive motion, as if to fend off an evil eye. Elara felt a chill crawl up her spine that had nothing to do with the temperature. The fear in this town wasn’t just of the vampires anymore. It was twisting into something else. Something aimed at her.

Back at the ranch, the familiar solitude felt different. It was tainted now, menacing. As she bolted the door that evening, she felt as if she were locking herself in with a threat, not just locking one out. The baby was active, its movements strong and relentless. She tried to read a book, one of Jed’s old paperbacks, but the words blurred. Brody’s voice kept replaying in her head. Drawn by something.

She blew out the lamp and lay down on the bed, her hand resting on her stomach. She tried to feel what Jed had felt—the simple, pure love for the life within. But all she could feel was a deep, gnawing unease. The baby gave a sudden, violent kick, so hard it stole her breath. And in that instant, something shifted in her perception. It was like a veil tearing for a fraction of a second. She didn't see it with her eyes, but she felt it, sensed it. She could feel the slow, steady beat of Gideon’s heart out in the barn. She could feel the frantic, terrified pulse of a field mouse hiding beneath the floorboards. And beyond that, out in the vast, consuming darkness, she could feel other things. Cold, hungry things. She could feel their thirst. A deep, hollow, aching need. They were scattered, miles apart, but they were all… listening. Waiting. Drawn. And the center point, the tuning fork that was making them all vibrate with this terrible, resonant hunger, was the new, frantic, impossibly strong heartbeat inside her own body. The silence of the land wasn't empty at all. It was full of a terrible, rapt attention, and her unborn child was the object of its fascination. The fortress she had built was for nothing. The danger wasn't outside. It was already in.A gasp tore from her throat, a ragged, choked sound that was utterly consumed by the silence. The sensation faded as quickly as it had arrived, the veil dropping back into place, leaving her shivering in a cold sweat. But the knowledge of it remained, seared into her mind. She lay perfectly still, her breath caught in her lungs, her ears straining. She heard only the familiar sounds: the creak of the house settling, the distant, lonely cry of the windmill. But she knew. Underneath it all, the listening continued. The attention was a physical pressure against her skin, a low hum in the base of her skull.

Her hand, which had rested on her belly with such casual, maternal affection, was now rigid, the fingers splayed as if touching something venomous. This child, Jed's child, her baby… was a lure. A beacon in the darkness, pulsing out a signal that only the monsters could hear. A dinner bell. The thought was so grotesque, so profoundly wrong, that a wave of nausea rolled through her. She fought the urge to be sick, pressing her lips together, her knuckles white where she gripped the thin quilt. Was this why they took Jed? Had they sensed it in him, too? A latent potential, a flavor in the bloodline that would blossom in his offspring? The memory of his head resting on her stomach, his quiet joy, was now a portrait of monstrous irony. He had been listening to a heartbeat that would call his killers to his wife's door.

She sat up, swinging her legs over the side of the bed. The floorboards were cool against her bare feet. The house no longer felt safe; it felt like the center of a target. Every shadow that the moonlight cast through the gaps in the shutters seemed to deepen, to coalesce. She thought of the old woman in Redemption, her dark eyes and the quick, protective sign she had made. It wasn't just a general ward against evil. It had been for her. At her. The whispers Brody had mentioned… they weren’t just rumors. They were a recognition. The land itself, and the people who knew how to listen to it, had sensed the change. They knew something was coming. Or rather, they knew what was drawing them in.

The anger from before, the clean, sharp anger at the wastefulness of the leeches, was gone. In its place was a new kind of fear, colder and more complex. It was a fear mixed with a terrible, dawning horror at her own body and the life it harbored. She was the cause. Her pregnancy, this miracle she had cherished in the face of her grief, was an existential threat not just to her, but to everything around her. The steers weren't a careless snack; they were appetizers. They were testing the perimeter, circling, sniffing the air, their dead-smelling breath already fogging the windows of her home. They were waiting for the meal to be ready.

She couldn’t stay. The realization was as stark and brutal as the landscape outside. The fence was a joke, the bolts on the door a child’s fantasy of security. To stay here was to wait for the inevitable, to sit in the center of the web until the spiders arrived. She stood up, her movements stiff, and walked to the window. Peering through a crack in the shutter, she saw the moon-drenched plains, a sea of silver and black. It looked peaceful, asleep. But she could feel the wakefulness out there now, a thousand pinpricks of cold, hungry awareness all pointed in her direction. Her direction. She had to run. Not to Redemption, where fear and superstition would make her a pariah, but away. Somewhere they wouldn’t think to look. Somewhere this terrible summons couldn't reach. The baby kicked, a hard, demanding thump against her ribs, and for the first time, the feeling didn't bring a smile. It felt like a countdown.## Chapter 2

The revelation did not bring paralysis. It brought a terrifying, galvanic energy that jolted her from her stupor. The need to move was a physical command, as primal and insistent as the baby’s kicks. She dressed in the dark, her fingers fumbling with buttons and laces, her mind racing far ahead of her body. Every second spent in the house was a second too long. The walls seemed to be breathing in time with the low hum of attention she could now feel from the surrounding darkness. She was a lamb in a pen, bleating for the wolves to come, and the pen was her own skin. She had to break the pattern, to run until the signal her child was sending out grew faint, distorted by distance, lost in the static of the world.

Her preparations were a blur of desperate efficiency. She grabbed a canvas pack and began stuffing it with the lean essentials of a life on the run. A slab of dried beef, a bag of parched corn, two full canteens of water. From a locked chest at the foot of her bed, she pulled out boxes of ammunition. The heavy brass of the revolver cartridges, the satisfying heft of the shotgun shells. She paused, her hand hovering over the silver-laced buckshot she’d made with Jed one long afternoon, melting down her grandmother’s tarnished spoons. They’d laughed about it, calling it their insurance against the boogeyman. The laughter died in her memory now, replaced by the chilling certainty that she didn't have nearly enough. She took it all. Jed’s compass, a tarnished brass instrument that always found north, and a creased, sweat-stained map of the territories went into a side pocket. Her gaze fell on a small, framed photograph on the nightstand: she and Jed on their wedding day, squinting in the bright sun, his arm slung around her shoulder, both of them beaming with a hope that now seemed impossibly naive. She left it. She couldn't afford the weight of memories.

Outside, the pre-dawn air was cool and carried the scent of dust and dry sage. The moon was a bone-white sliver, offering little light. It was enough. She moved to the small corral where a half-dozen cattle milled nervously, their breath pluming in the chill. She couldn’t take them, and she couldn't leave them penned up as a convenient buffet for the things that would surely come looking for her. With a heavy heart and the metallic taste of failure in her mouth, she unlatched the gate and swung it wide. “Go on,” she whispered, her voice a raw scrape. “Get.” They stared at her with wide, placid eyes before one, then another, trotted tentatively out into the open range, dissolving into the gloom. It was a severing, a cutting of the final tie that bound her to this place. She was no longer a rancher. She was just prey.

Saddling Gideon was the last act. The familiar feel of the worn leather, the horse’s warm, solid presence, was the only comfort in a world that had suddenly tilted on its axis. He seemed to sense the urgency, the fear rolling off her in waves, standing unnaturally still as she cinched the saddle and tied the pack down behind it. She stroked his neck, burying her face for a moment in his coarse mane. “It’s just you and me, boy,” she murmured into his warmth. “And the little one.” She swung herself into the saddle, the shotgun now resting in a scabbard beside her leg, its stock a cold, hard promise against her thigh. She turned Gideon not east toward Redemption, but west, toward the jagged, broken lands and the distant teeth of the mountains. It was a direction of last resort, a place where the maps grew vague and the water holes were few and far between. It was a place no sane person would go. And that was its only appeal.

She did not look back. To look back was to acknowledge the totality of what she was losing: the house she had shared with her husband, the land they had bled for, the life she had imagined for herself and her child. All of it was being sacrificed to the terrible, silent summons emanating from her own womb. As Gideon picked his way out onto the plains, the first hint of dawn was a faint grey wound on the eastern horizon. The light was not a comfort. It was a spotlight, revealing her, a lone rider fleeing across an empty stage. The listening presence she had felt in the house did not fade with distance. It shifted, stretched, a vast and subtle net of awareness reorienting itself to her new position. They knew she was moving. The hunt had begun. The baby shifted inside her, a slow, lazy roll, oblivious. A life she would protect with her last breath, from a danger that very life had called down upon them. The irony was a stone in her gut, heavy and cold. The sun cracked the horizon, and Elara Vance rode west, a fugitive from her own blood.The sun, which had for so long been a merciless hammer, was now a guardian. Elara rode hard under its white-hot gaze, pushing Gideon until his flanks were dark with sweat and his breath came in ragged bursts. The land offered no cover, just an endless, undulating expanse of cracked earth, hardy scrub, and the skeletal remains of long-dead trees. Every hour on the move was an hour the night-crawlers couldn’t follow. She felt a grim satisfaction in the heat, in the punishing glare that would be lethal to her pursuers. For the first time in her life, she prayed for the day to last forever, for the sun to burn a permanent hole in the sky and never set. But the world kept turning, and the shadows of the mesas began to stretch like grasping fingers across the plains.

Her body ached with a depth of weariness she had never known. The constant, jostling motion of the horse was a torment to her back, and the weight of the child felt like a leaden anchor pulling her down. She knew she had to stop, for her own sake and for Gideon’s. An hour before sunset, she found what she was looking for: a shallow overhang of sandstone carved out of a low bluff, barely deep enough to conceal them from a casual glance. It wasn’t much, but it offered a view of the long, empty slope she had just ascended, and the rock at her back felt solid and real. She slid from the saddle, her legs trembling, and tethered Gideon close, where he could share the meager shelter. The routine of caring for the horse—rubbing him down, giving him a careful portion of water—was a flimsy shield against the encroaching dread. She ate without tasting, the dried beef tough and salty in her mouth, her eyes fixed on the horizon as the sun surrendered the sky to a blaze of defiant, bloody color.

As darkness consumed the last vestiges of light, the world transformed. The familiar landscape became an alien terrain of menacing shapes and bottomless shadows. The wind, which had been a hot breath during the day, now whispered and moaned through the rocks with a thousand different voices, each one a potential threat. And with the dark, the listening returned. It was no longer a vague pressure but a focused, directional hum, a vibration in her teeth. They were out there, awake and moving. The silence of her ranch had been full of their attention; the silence of the open plains was full of their intent.

She sat with her back against the rock, the shotgun laid across her lap, its cold steel a poor substitute for the warmth of another human being. She didn’t dare sleep. She listened, her senses stretched to their breaking point. She heard the scuttling of a lizard, the distant howl of a lone coyote, the steady grind of Gideon’s teeth as he worried a stalk of dry grass. Then, the baby stirred, a sharp, insistent kick that made her gasp. In that instant, the low thrum of their collective attention snapped into sharp focus. It was as if a flare had gone up in the darkness, pinpointing her exact location. She felt a wave of cold awareness wash over the land from the east, a ripple of predatory interest. They had her scent. They were turning.

The night passed in an agony of vigilance. She dozed in short, nightmarish bursts, jerking awake at every skitter of gravel, her heart a frantic drum against her ribs. But they did not come. When the first grey light of dawn finally broke the eastern horizon, a wave of relief so profound it felt like sickness washed over her. She had survived. She had been wrong. They were far away, their senses confused by the distance. She allowed herself a moment of fragile hope, a single, deep breath of the cool morning air. It was a mistake. As she stood to stretch her stiff limbs, her eyes caught something on the sandy ground just beyond the edge of their shelter, no more than twenty feet from where Gideon stood.

Tracks. They were not the boot prints of a man, nor the paw prints of an animal. They were long and narrow, the shape of a bare human foot but unnaturally elongated, with a deep impression at the toe as if the creature pushed off with inhuman force. There was a set leading toward her camp, and another leading away. They had come while she slept. They had stood there, in the darkness, watching her. They had smelled the air, tasted her proximity, and for a reason she couldn't comprehend, they had moved on. A faint, cloying scent hung in the air, the smell of a damp cellar and spoiled meat. They hadn't attacked. It was a message. We know where you are. We can get to you whenever we want. The hunt wasn't a race; it was a game, and they were letting her run, just to prolong the sport.A cold dread, sharp and clarifying, replaced the initial shock. The hope she had foolishly harbored curdled into rage. This wasn't a hunt; it was a leisurely stroll, an exercise in terror for their own amusement. They hadn’t attacked because the kill was not the point. The point was her fear. The point was the running. She was their entertainment, a frightened mouse let loose in a vast, empty room for the cat’s pleasure. She grabbed a dead branch of greasewood and, with frantic, sweeping motions, obliterated the tracks. She scrubbed the sand clean, an absurd and pathetic act of defiance, as if she could erase their presence, their knowledge, by wiping away their footprints. But the cloying, subterranean scent of them lingered in the air, a stain that could not be scoured away.

There was no more rest. She forced down a mouthful of water, splashed the rest of her ration on Gideon's nose, and mounted up. The sun was barely clear of the horizon, but she spurred the horse on with a grim urgency. The day’s ride was a punishing ordeal. The landscape devolved from open plains into a fractured maze of arroyos and canyons, a land of sharp edges and sudden drops. The sun beat down, reflecting off the pale rock until the world was a white, shimmering glare. Her paranoia became a constant companion, a second rider at her shoulder. Every rock formation seemed to hold a waiting figure, every gust of wind sounded like a dry, bloodless whisper. She no longer trusted the open spaces, seeing them as killing fields, and she hugged the twisting canyon walls, the rock a constant, oppressive presence to her right and left.

Hours later, deep in the afternoon, the baby woke. It wasn't a kick this time, but a long, slow turning, a powerful repositioning that sent a ripple of movement across her belly. And with it, that now-familiar sensation: the hum of attention from the east intensified, a dozen cold minds turning in unison, their focus sharpening like a lens. They had been tracking her slow progress, but this, this powerful movement from the child, was like a shout in a quiet room. It gave them a fresh, strong fix on her position. A wave of revulsion, so alien and unwelcome it made her feel faint, washed through her. She pressed her palm hard against her stomach, a desperate, instinctive gesture not to soothe, but to smother. To quiet the beacon. "Be still," she hissed through her teeth, the words meant for the life inside her, for the innocent author of her doom. The child, of course, did not listen.

She knew she couldn't risk another night in the open. A simple overhang wouldn’t do. They could stand twenty feet away and watch her again, enjoying the scent of her terror before melting away with the dawn. She needed to be sealed in. A fortress. The thought led her to scan the canyon walls with a new purpose. She wasn't just looking for shelter anymore; she was looking for a tomb. An hour later, she found it. A dark slash in the rock face, almost perfectly concealed by a recent rockfall. It was the entrance to an old prospector's mine, long abandoned. A gust of cool, mineral-scented air breathed from its mouth. Gideon shied away from it, his ears flat, but Elara dismounted and tied his reins to a sturdy rock, stroking his trembling neck. "It's alright, boy. It's better than what's out there."

Taking the shotgun from its scabbard, she ducked under the low lintel of rock and stepped inside. The temperature dropped twenty degrees. The darkness was absolute, a thick, palpable blackness that swallowed the light from the entrance just a few feet in. She fumbled in her pack for the small tin of matches and a candle stub. The match flared, a small, brave sun in the immense dark, and she lit the wick. The candlelight pushed back a small circle of shadow, revealing a narrow, hand-hewn tunnel shored up with ancient, rotting timbers. The air was stale but clean, free of the leeches' foul odor. She ventured deeper, her footsteps echoing unnervingly. Ten yards in, the tunnel opened into a small chamber where the original miner had obviously lived and worked. A rusted pickaxe lay against the wall, and the remains of a wooden crate sat in the corner. It was on the far wall of the chamber that she saw them.

Carved into the sandstone, crude but unmistakable, were symbols. She ran her hand over them, the candlelight throwing the shallow grooves into relief. There were suns with intricate rays, spirals that mirrored the shape of a snail’s shell, and in the center, a complex, star-like sigil. It was this last one that made her breath catch. She had seen it before, or something very like it. It was the shape the old woman in Redemption had made with her fingers, a more elaborate version of the warding gesture. Beneath the symbols, more crudely scratched, were words. The letters were shaky, desperate. *They thirst for the new bloom. The sun is the only shield. The stone remembers the light.* It wasn't a prospector's journal. It was a warning. A prayer. Someone else had hidden in this very spot, from this very same threat. The stone remembers the light. Elara looked at the solid rock surrounding her. A fortress. But the final line of the inscription, almost lost in the shadows at the bottom, sent a fresh spike of ice into her heart. *But the hunger comes from within.*## Chapter 3

The words on the stone were a judgment delivered from the grave. *The hunger comes from within.* Elara snatched her hand back from the carving as if the rock itself were hot iron. The flickering candlelight cast her shadow, huge and distorted, against the wall behind her, a monstrous silhouette of her pregnant form. The air in the mine, once a cool refuge, now felt suffocating, heavy with the weight of this ancient, terrible truth. The "new bloom." The phrase echoed in her mind, a poetic and horrifyingly apt description for the life she carried. It wasn’t just a beacon. It was kin.

As if in answer to the thought, the baby moved. It wasn’t a kick or a roll this time. It was a sharp, sudden pang that radiated from her center, a feeling she had never experienced before. It was a hollow ache, a deep, gnawing emptiness that was not her own. For a split second, she felt a phantom thirst on her tongue, an instinctive, predatory craving that was so alien, so profoundly wrong, it made her knees buckle.
